On Ideological Possession That an ideology can “possess” a person strikes me as a fruitful way of revealing fundamental errors in the way people think about their world. The word ideology literally means the logic or study of an idea, a formulated thought. If I say I have an idea of a chair I can oppose to that idea the fact of the specific chair in which I am sitting. The idea of a chair is a concept that references a class of characteristic objects. This distinction between the idea of a chair and a chair whose physical existence can be verified in prescribed ways instantiates the broad philosophical contrast between relations of ideas and matters of fact. When the geometer, for example, measures the earth, what he actually measures, for a host of practical reasons, is a planetary model. The model itself arises as a consequence of collecting appropriate and relevant data. Beginning with a rough idea of the planet, data modifies the developing model as the model guides further productive inquiry. In principle, there is no theoretical end to this dynamic reciprocity; inquiry ceases when understanding “is good enough” to accomplish the original purpose. Without the restraints imposed by scientific method, political philosophy roughly mimics the distinction between relations of ideas and matters of fact. Without such method, of course, ideas cannot be verified as objectively true. That lack, however, does not lessen the significance of political philosophy; nor does the lack suggest that facts cannot be urged in support of one perspective over another. What is sought in politics is a convincing narrative. Arguments are advanced to support specific claims, but the narrative itself must reflect an embodied knowledge of the culture if it is to persuade. Ideologies clearly reflect relations of ideas, and while facts are cited, in politics they notoriously admit of any number of competing and even conflicting interpretations. That Marx’s labor theory of value is demonstrably false hardly diminishes the enthusiasm of his supporters and followers. When errors multiply without affecting the credibility of an ideology, we know we are in the presence of ideological possession: the ideas themselves, in some fundamental sense, are conceived to be true independent of observable experience. Indeed, the traditional relation between the relations of ideas and matters of fact are inverted: what can be admitted as “facts” are exclusively those phenomena posited by the ideology. Ideas are held to constitute the real; there is no room for empiricism, for the correcting of error. It is, admittedly, not the job of politicians, or even public intellectuals, to admit error in fundamental propositions when legislative action is demanded. That is the function of a society’s highly educated academic elite, its philosophers. Unfortunately, the academic elite can be corrupted by the lure of power, money, and privilege provided, intentionally or not, by government. The only way to avert such corruption is by funding the academy from private, competing resources. A college or university funded by a large corporation, to take a  “worst-case” scenario, may reflect that organization’s parochial interests; multiple academies funded by different private groups, however, is more likely to provide a basis of self-correcting inquiry within academic life: no one group will command monopoly power over the what counts as knowledge, a situation that characterizes the universities and schools today in the United States.
